summary: This is a July 2003 audit report by the U.S. Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General (OIG) reviewing the application controls of the Federal Bureau of Prisons' (BOP) SENTRY inmate database system. The audit identified weaknesses in supervisory reviews, audit logs, access controls, and computer matching of transaction data, concluding the system was at low risk but recommending improvements to data integrity and security.

events.title: SENTRY Contingency Plan Test
events.description: The BOP tested its SENTRY database contingency plan, as confirmed to the OIG prior to the report's issuance.

events.title: Planned Enforcement of BP-337 Form Policy
events.description: The BOP's target date to notify all Community Corrections Offices (CCOs) of the mandatory requirement to use the BP-337 form as the sole source document for inputting initial inmate data.

events.title: Target Date for Exception Report Distribution
events.description: The BOP's target date to begin creating and forwarding SENTRY audit log exception reports to the Information Security Officer on at least a weekly basis.

events.title: Target Date for SENTRY Manual Revision
events.description: The BOP's target date to complete a revision of the SENTRY General Use Manual (GUM), including correct procedures for loading initial inmate data.

events.title: Target Date for Security Guide Update
events.description: The BOP's target date to update the 'SENTRY System Security Guide' to require routine generation and review of exception reports.

keyFacts: The SENTRY database is the BOP's primary system for tracking over 165,000 federal inmates, processing over 1 million transactions daily.
The OIG audit found data entry errors at BOP offices, including incorrect offense codes, commitment dates, and missing fine information in inmate records.

A significant access control weakness was identified: users with limited profiles could access restricted data (like sensitive medical records) when logged onto terminals configured for higher-authorization users.
The BOP's 'SENTRY System Security Guide' did not require routine review of audit log exception reports, and such reports were not being generated or reviewed.
The BOP agreed with most OIG recommendations but requested further discussion on two recommendations (redesigning and modifying the BP-337 form) before providing an official response.
